image.altText: A blue-gloved hand holds a flame under a glass pipe which has white smoke coming out

props.synopsis: A District Court judge says communities are being "completely and utterly destroyed" by methylamphetamine, while sentencing a Kimberley man for his role as a courier in a significant drug operation.

title.children: Drug courier's sentencing highlights outback WA's growing meth problem

image.altText: Tamak Vijay walking outside a Perth court with his head down

props.synopsis: A driving assessor who indecently assaulted three women while they were in the car with him will be allowed to remain on a Perth council.

title.children: Belmont councillor who indecently assaulted women during driving tests doesn't have to resign despite conviction

image.altText: Two people stand in front of a yellow submarine.

props.synopsis: After years out of sight, and some serious restoration work, Geraldton's iconic yellow submarine has found a new berth, overlooking the ocean where it was once trialled.Â

title.children: Almost lost to the scrap heap, a yellow submarine resurfaces in all its golden glory

image.altText: A herd of sheep in a dry paddock on a farm.

props.synopsis: The federal government will provide an additional $32 million to help WA's sheep industry transition away from live exports, bringing the total support package to $139 million.

title.children: Backlash from WA farmers after live export ban prompts extra $32 million in federal government help

image.altText: Two men at a table with a crowd of people behind them

props.synopsis: Stuart McCullough was paid almost $500,000 from the taxpayer and farmer-funded Australian Wool Innovation organisation to leave his job. WoolProducers has questioned the payout as farmers do it "exceptionally tough".

title.children: Former ag boss receives $480k payout to leave job as farmers do it 'exceptionally tough'

image.altText: A big shark near a very small boat.

props.synopsis: An angler's close encounter with a 4-metre shark near the popular tourist town of Exmouth in Western Australia creates a flurry of excitement online.

title.children: WA's north treated to 'weirdly fantastic' sighting of 4-metre great white shark

image.altText: Woman sitting in a hospital gown holding her sisters hand

props.synopsis:
Two sisters describe their unbreakable bond after life-saving kidney transplant surgery.

Â 

Â

title.children: Kate celebrates life after being gifted a second kidney, this time from her sister

image.altText: A close up of the Premier wearing a white hard hat

props.synopsis: WA's Town of Port Hedland council has passed a motion urging state and federal governments to suspend COVID-19 vaccines, prompting the Premier to say they should "stick to their knitting" and stop spreading unverified claims.

title.children: 'Off the rails' council backs COVID conspiracy and calls for vaccines to be scrapped

image.altText: A woman in a yellow hi-vis shirt crouches with her two children on the ground, while smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: A new childcare centre that will nearly triple the number of placements on offer in a fast-developing WA town is welcomed by local parents, who say they have had to endure waiting times of more than eight months.

title.children: A 'childcare desert' in the Wheatbelt town of Moora will more than double its capacity

image.altText: Cameron Burgess  lies on the pitch

props.synopsis: The Socceroos took the lead thanks to an own goal, but were then pegged back by one of their own as they battled to a 1-1 draw against Japan in Saitama.

title.children: Socceroos held to valiant draw by Japan in Saitama

image.altText: Albanese in a high-vis yellow vest speaks in front of a microphone in front of a green sign

props.synopsis: Household batteries could form part of a plan to make electricity cheaper for low- to middle-income earners before the next election.

title.children: Labor mulls 'electrify everything' pre-election household plan

image.altText: An older man poses on an armchair with one leg crossed over the other.

props.synopsis: George Negus's frosty interview with Maragaret Thatcher became famous, but it sparked a flurry of calls between Canberra and London and a demand by the then-British prime minister to have the full interview released without edits.

title.children: From high-school teacher to celebrated journalist. George Negus remembered for his most famous interview

image.altText: A row of damaged beige tents stands, some without covers, as two women look on from the background

props.synopsis: Israeli military strikes kill at least 40 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip as Israeli forces tighten their squeeze around Jabalia in the north of the enclave, amid fierce battles with Hamas-led fighters.

title.children: 40 Palestinians killed in one day as UN says Israel 'cutting off northern Gaza completely'

image.altText: A man dressed in a smoking jacket and sailors hat

props.synopsis: A lawyer representing the estranged wife of ex-AFL star Ricky Olarenshaw claims his client is the victim of dodgy police work, exploitation, and threats by another Australian man to bring in "very powerful people."Â

title.children: Allegations of threats and wads of cash emerge in case of Bali sex parlour with alleged links to ex-AFL star

image.altText: A man wearing a green jacket and hat holding tomatoes.

props.synopsis:
Tomato growers placed into quarantine after the discovery of the tomato brown rugose virus say authorities should have been better prepared for the arrival of the virus.

Â 

Â 

Â 

Â

title.children: 'Devastated': Tens of millions of dollars in losses smash Australian tomato farmers

image.altText: Penny Wong wears a maroon blazer as she speaks at a press conference

props.synopsis: The Foreign Minister said she didn't believe "we gain anything by shouting each other down" after being forced to stop her speech multiple times.

title.children: Pro-Palestinian protesters shout down Penny Wong as she delivers speech in Tasmania

image.altText: Black spherical pieces of debris along a beach. Seagulls are also pictured standing on the shore.

props.synopsis: Mysterious black spheres washed up on Coogee Beach on Tuesday. The beach has been closed until further notice as Randwick City Council works to safely remove the debris and investigates.

title.children: Sydney's Coogee Beach shut after discovery of mysterious black balls

image.altText: A faded car sticker that reads King Island: Think Buy Live Local

props.synopsis: Despite a high price tag, the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme is just not working the way it should.

title.children: This costly scheme helps small businesses, so why has almost no one on King Island got a good thing to say about it?

image.altText: Dan Houston celebrates a goal with his arm raised

props.synopsis: Dan Houston has been granted his wish to join Collingwood after the Magpies agreed on a three-team deal with Port Adelaide and the Gold Coast Suns, while West Coast was grilled over a controversial trade move.

title.children: Monster three-team, five-player trade sends Dan Houston to Collingwood

image.altText: A monk with a shaved head sits in a saffron robe with bare arms folded.

props.synopsis: There are some shocking statistics around the violence and abuse children in Cambodia suffer, and a new program led by the country's venerated Buddhist monks is helping to drive change inside families.Â

title.children: Monks leading the way on child protection in Cambodia

image.altText: A woman in a white long-sleeve and collared shirt with shoulder-length black hair sits behind a desk

props.synopsis: In the tightly-controlled world of K-pop, the public airing of complaints is rare, with a boardroom drama continuing to play out that could affect the future of one of its most successful bands.

title.children: Hanni of NewJeans speaks about bullying and harassment in K-pop industry

image.altText: A rendered image of a large two-towered white building surrounded by trees.

props.synopsis: Build-to-rent is the latest craze in property, with advocates saying it can help solve issues with housing in Australia. But how has the concept performed overseas?Â

title.children: Build-to-rent is rapidly expanding in Australia. But will it help fix the housing crisis?

image.altText: Front on view of an icebreaker ship.

props.synopsis: Hobart's status as the gateway to Antarctica has been secured after the federal government agreed to fund a new home port for Australia's icebreaker, but the Tasmanian government will be on the hook for the cost of a refuelling solution â something which has been a problem of late.

title.children: Port funding announced to secure Hobart as 'gateway to Antarctica'

image.altText: A large, white coral-like creature is swaying in the water.

props.synopsis: On the bottom of the Pacific Ocean, near fissures spewing hot water, a submersible stumbled upon a thriving community of animals living in cavities below.

title.children: 'We could not believe our eyes': Worms and snails discovered living under the sea floor

image.altText: View across the water with surfers in the foreground paddling and the highrises of Surfers Paradiose in the background

props.synopsis: Locals' bitterness about the southern Gold Coast's rapid transformation could flip this LNP seat to an independent in the upcoming state election.

title.children: Growing pains are crippling the LNP's most marginal Queensland electorate

image.altText: A close up image of recycled cardboard

props.synopsis: Plans to build what would be Australia's largest plastics recycling plant in the NSW Southern Highlands have advanced despite community opposition and environmental concerns.

title.children: Residents outraged by proposal to put Australia's largest recycling plant 200 metres from their homes

image.altText: A graphic showing a kid sitting in the dark looking tired with a bright computer screen in their face.

props.synopsis: With parents worried about screen time and teachers dealing with AI-assisted plagiarism, some experts say it might be time for education to change.

title.children: 'I miss reading an actual book': Screen time and AI use far exceeds guidelines amid calls to rethink bans

image.altText: Troy Bell walks outside a court building holding a note pad.

props.synopsis: Independent Mount Gambier MP Troy Bell says he will fight the jury's guilty verdicts and hopes to clear his name while continuing to represent his community.

title.children: MP found guilty of fraud offences vows to clear his name

props.synopsis: Three years after a tiny pest began killing trees across Perth, authorities are sticking to one method â cutting down established trees in the hope of eradicating it. What will it take for the city to learn to live with the shot-hole borer?

title.children: 'No other country in the world has attempted to eradicate this': Is it time to change tack on the shot-hole borer?

image.altText: A woman in a yellow vest passes a piece of paper to a woman wearing a cream jumper and red skirt.

props.synopsis: Canberrans will head to the polls on Saturday to choose the 11th Legislative Assembly. Here's everything you need to know about where to vote, what time the polls close, how to fill in ballot papers and when we're likely to know results.Â

title.children: Everything you need to know about voting in the ACT election including where, when and how

image.altText: Albanese and Haydon stand shoulder to shoulder smiling, the prime minister's lodge behind them.

props.synopsis: The Copacabana property on the NSW Central Coast is touted as being "clifftop perfection" and features expansive ocean views.Â

title.children: 'I earn a good income': Albanese buys $4.3 million clifftop property to be close to future wife's family

image.altText: Two small boats with divers abroad approach a large underwater shipwreck

props.synopsis: New Zealand's defence minister has dismissed calls for an apology, saying the NZ Defence Force was "deeply traumatised" by the sinking of HMNZS Manawanui.

title.children: 'Nothing but sadness' in the village near where a NZ Navy ship sank as locals lose livelihoods

image.altText: A closeup of stethoscope resting on a doctor's chest.

props.synopsis: Doctors from the UK, Ireland and New Zealand will have their ability to practise in Australia fast-tracked from next week, but the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners says the move lacks detail and could put patients at risk.

title.children: Foreign doctors from select countries will have applications fast tracked under new rules

image.altText: People watch a TV screen with smoke rising out of a forest area.

props.synopsis: North Korea blows up the north section of unused roads once linked to the South, with the rivals exchanging threats days after the North claimed that its rival flew drones over its capital, Pyongyang.

title.children: North Korea blows up parts of inter-Korean roads and rails
